Well if this game doesnt make it obvious that we are going to be all in a Matrix state in the next 20 years then nothing will. Its nothing short of astounding.  If you can walk around and bend down and look over the sets you will be amazed.  This took a lot of creativity to come up with.  It is like HR Geiger artwork mixed with MC Escher set to an amazing soundtrack.  There were a couple of times when the thing that was supposed to be there was not or had moved around behind something and gotten hidden in the intricate sets but other than that it works like a charm.  I'd play it again just to go through the trippy visuals again.  Makes you wonder what the future will bring.  Whats funny is if this game came out 10 years ago everyone would be freaking but now its like eh.  Totally worth getting worth the experiece.  I almost never take time to review games but man this one was so good I got to give the developers some credit.  Its amazing what these small teams an do nowadays.

FORM这个游戏是我目前玩过的最精致的VR解谜游戏。视觉效果炫酷，音乐大气磅礴，谜题也很充分的利用了VR的优势，体验很震撼。
不过缺憾也是显而易见的，那就是游戏真的是太短了，初见1个小时就能玩通，然后就只能用来听音乐（虽然是很炫酷的音乐）。真希望开发团队能再开发些新关卡或者在他们的下一个游戏中能有很长的游戏流程和同等优秀的游戏设计。
总之，游戏确实是值得一玩的，价格上如果能打个对折或者更高的折扣完全可以考虑入手，很期待这个团队的新作品。

两个隐藏成就的达成条件：
Asking For Trouble: [spoiler] 在游戏要求的剧情触发之前拉十次Blast Door的那个大拉杆（左手边）[/spoiler]
Got Back to Work: [spoiler] 在扫描陨石样本之前把桌子上所有能拿起来的东西都扫描一遍 [/spoiler]

我一直期待The Room这个系列可以做成VR游戏，因为怎么想它的操作系统和解谜方式都非常适合VR。
而Form这个游戏就和The Room非常像了，尤其是前面那个可以旋转的正方体上的解谜，就非常The Room。

说回Form这个游戏，优点很明显，场景非常酷炫，并且剧情（虽然不明所以）也很有趣。而且有些场景做得真是，我一边玩一边产生了，“我是不是要打开真理之门了”和“我薛帕德要和收割者融合成为银河系之神了”的感觉。

而且解谜难度适中，（在硬核解谜玩家眼力应该算是难度太低）对于VR的体验来说这种解谜很合适，如果太难反而会影响VR体验，而且很累。一个小时的体验就非常合理了，希望可以出后续作品。

WOW... just WOW! This, Ladies and Gentlemen, is the very essence of VR. THIS is what VR should be like. The graphics, the effects, the audio and the story - absolutly gorgeous! Chapeau! I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a brainy entertaining and outerworldly experience.

That said, here comes the "but" to all the above: IT. IS. TOO. SHORT. And while it might seem unfair me ranting over the shortness of VR titles with regards to this marvellous work, there is something basically wrong with the road developers take in VR. I know, I know. It costs a lot of time and money to produce a AAA title with native VR support and the market is still small and whatnot. But y'all have to start somewhere. This title has the potential to be the AAA title users wait for. But under two hours playtime? Been there, done that. I started reacting to this akward premature de-gamjulation within VR Titles by simply refunding them. And while this - I know - is the absolute WRONG way, as I am withdrawing money from people that need it, if they want to create titles that are longer than the average attentionspan of a congolese-red-butt-macaque, I am tired of paying up for too short or too crappy titles (this one is just short and brilliant!). Offer something more, and I would pay double and triple including unconditional loyalty and heartfelt love. I will be watching the creators of this title closely and if and when we apporach a reasonably amout of playtime, I'll be throwing money at them with both hands!

This is a great, polished, enjoyable 45-minute to an hour experience.  The animations in particular are AMAZING, on the level of Valve's "The Lab".  The puzzles themselves are simple, the story is light but appropriate for the setting.

I do wish it cost $10 instead of $15 given the relatively short length, but with production values this high I'm fine with what I paid.  I'll run some friends through this one too - a great "here's what storytelling in VR can do that flat screens can't" game.

35187614.review: This is a great VR experience.  Except for a couple of on rails teleportation sequences, It's entirely stand-in-place, so it doesn't require much physical play space and avoids issues with locomotion.  Gameplay involves a lot of touch interaction with geometry and physical contraption puzzles which is pretty basic as far as puzzlers go, but novel and well implemented in VR.  The plot is enigmatic, and short.  The game seems like it's structured for a 3rd act, but ends abruptly which is a disappointment.  However, there are some genuinely delight and awe inspiring moments supported by great sound design and visually intriguing environments.  I think we're going to reach a point in the evolution of VR gameplay where simple manipulation mechanics start to feel like an adult version of a toddler's block slot toy, but at this point in the arc, just having things to look at and do in VR is entertaining, and FORM is a worthwhile environment to spend some time in.  Props to the developer for being responsive.  I reported a crash bug (turned out I had an old build), and got a personal reply within hours.

WOW!

There were so many moments during my playthrough of FORM where I stopped and stared in absolute awe of the stunning visuals. This type of game is the reason I got the Vive. The puzzles themselves didn't feel overly complex, but were still satisfying to complete. The interaction with the puzzles, and the interactions it had with the environment was spectacular!

This is a game that's reminiscent of escape the room type puzzle games. It's not a particularly long game, it takes around an hour to an hour and a half to finish. The puzzles are on the easy side as well, but not so easy that you'll be bored with them. 

What really sets this game apart (and justifies the price point vs. length) is the aesthetic of the game. It takes you into a world that you'll never find in real life, and allows you to experience it through the magic of VR. It's a mix of the strange and the futuristic, and it makes you feel like you're in another world while you're solving these puzzles. If you want to experience one of the more mind blowing environments in VR, check out this game. My only complaint is that there isn't more.

FORM is great VR in any respect. Sound, colors, geometry and the feel to VR is one of the best experiences there is. The game itself is not unlike the "The Room" games. You solve similar to "The Room" puzzles using spacial sense in a VR environment.

The only drawback is the very, VERY limited playtime. Even if you don't rush and look at the beautiful scenery this game does not take any longer than about 1 hour. 1 hour now is great entertainment, but for 19,99 Euros this is too expensive! The mentioned game "The Room" for example gives you a 3 hour gameplay with similar entertainment for only 4,99 Euros. It's not VR, but the puzzles in game are very similar.

So it's hard for me to recommend this game for the original price. It's also hard for me, to not recommend it, since it is VR at it's best. I got it for a discount -40%. It's still 11,99 Euros which I still find quite expensive for a 1 hour game.

All things considered, I can recommend this game, [b]IF[/b] you can manage a discount on it. [b]Do not(!) buy it for the regular price[/b], because I find it not worth 19,99 Euros for 1 hour PC gaming entertainment.

Genuinely a fascinating experience.  Nothing else quite like it or at this level of quality on the Vive at the time of review. 34504350.review:
TLDR: +looks great +transfers you to really different place +all unique puzles +kinda trippy experince 
-lenght ~+-hand alignment 

Ok, it was short. But I have to admit, it was some quality time. It's good that there was few warning reviews about shortness.

This game has many great ideas that would be great to see in other games aswell. Loved the looking sphere idea. Great movement (what little there was) from one spot to another with those light trails. Just the right amoung of surreal scenery. 

Something that doen't get used enough in vr (what I've seen) is 2d - 3d portal use. That some mere flat door frame holds whole scenery behind it. Actuallu that could have been used more here too. 

I see it would've been easy to extend this game by repeating same type of puzles over and over. Now it felt more unique without and unnecessary grinding. Once one problem was solved there wasnt any need to repeat same thing all over in different form. 

Something that broke some of the experiance was hand alignment. It felt strange to grab and operate with palms and not with fingertips. Though I got high hopes if this gets knuckles update some day. 34476376.review:
Seeing as its currently 40% off, I figured now is a good a time to put up a review of this thing.

Altho puzzley games arent usually my thing, I hadnt bought a VR game in a while (when this launched), so I took a chance with FORM. I found I was pleasantly surprised, what I remember to be most striking was how much care and effort went in to have this game so well polished.

The puzzle side of things were a bit easy, but that is a tricky thing to get right (and right for who?). I would rather slightly too easy than the opposite IMO, no frustration! The length (common VR theme!) is short. Without rushing or being a genius, I finished this in an hour or so, incl the credits. Other than the length, the game did cheap out a bit in the middle during a story clip, it was told to a static backdrop. But considering the time and effort to do things well in VR, I think it was the right decision, rather than make the game shorter (assuming it was a budget call).

If you havent played Simon, or done a jigsaw puzzle in years - like a normal person - then maybe its retro enough for you to enjoy it again, briefly.

FORM is a beautifully and lovingly crafted puzzle game. While short (about 1hr), at a discount is a worthwhile purchase.

A solid 8/10 for me. I *definitely* wouldn't mind if the conclusion felt more... conclusion-y, but I knew about the game's length, and bought it anyways- and it was *totally* worth it.

I did not expect a long game but it ended when I thought I had completed half of it. In addition the ending/outro could've been just a little bit longer with more things going on, as it is now it felt a bit lame compared to the actual game.

The puzzles are quite simple but not bad. They often occur in different variations, but they only became longer rather than more difficult. IMHO this game is more about experiencing awesome alien locations, and the puzzles only exist to give you something to do with your hands while watching everything around you.

At least one puzzle requires being able to tell different colors apart (red, orange, green and blue) so it could be difficult for color blind people. There was also one puzzle which required me to reach quite far above my head (I'm 186cm) and someone significanly shorter might have trouble completing it.

With all that having been said I still recommend this game, especially if you're able to get it on a sale, as long as you don't expect a long game or challenging puzzles.

I really want to like this game.  The graphics and sound are mighty impressive, and you can tell that a lot of effort went into making it.  If you can take the last bits of 2001: A Space Oddyssey and flesh it out, or view some of the more brilliant examples of the Demoscene (espcially ASD), that's basically the atmosphere of FORM.

But as for the gameplay and story, I was left wanting.  I'm guessing it's mostly the lack of exploration; there's no movement in the game except for popping between set pieces after accomplishing a series of easy puzzles.  This lack of exploraiton and lack of challenge felt... childish?  Literally square peg goes into square hole, play 4-color Simon, that sort of thing.  For as mind-bending graphics as the game has, I came in expecting something puzzles more non-euclidian like Antichamber, or something as challenging / exploratory as Talos Principle-- both games that a recent Reddit thread linked the game to.  Sadly FORM does not live up to those for gameplay.

The designs and environments whilst abstract and slightly 'oppressive' (for the lack of words for describing some higher dimensional geometrically inclined fever dream!) offer some genuinely creative moments of VR puzzling. I really must admire the care given to the experience, including the sense of progression and empowerment (particularly in the 'right' chamber) through the puzzles.

My only critiques would be that to those who are puzzle-savvy, it is possibly a little high on the price side for the time taken to complete the experience. My other critique is I was certainly yearning for more gameplay after completing it! I really wish it had a few more 'chambers' before resolving!

On a side note; I would say to those of you who like to 'throw your friends into VR'; this game would certainly be a good one for showcasing what VR can do.

32179428.review:
Simply put, FORM may be the most unexpectedly enjoyable VR experience I've played in recent memory. It's intensely atmospheric, VISUALLY STUNNING (let me repeat that in case you missed it - VISUALLY STUNNING), and polished in a way I've never seen before from such a small indie team. The animation quality, the sound design, the art style - they're all spectacular, and all combine perfectly to make for a very unique VR experience. 

Yes - it is short for a $20 game (with only 2 or so hours of gameplay)
No - the puzzles aren't groundbreaking (or complicated, really)
And no - there isn't much in terms of replayability...

BUT these flaws pale in comparison to everything FORM gets right. At a certain point, I didn't even mind if puzzles became repetitive because I was so invested in seeing what crazy environment I'd stumble into next. Solving puzzles was insanely satisfying simply due to the animation quality and auditory feedback, making each and every interaction with the world around you feel fantastic.

If you're strapped for cash, throw it on your Wishlist and wait for a sale - if not, definitely just pick this one up and enjoy the ride.

32166657.review:
Let's get the honesty out of the way first. Yes, this is a short game. A very short game in fact. Maybe an hour playthough if you take your time. But... it was an amazing hour! It feels like you have entered an alien mothership, and you're attempting to communicate with its primary entity through logic puzzles and sound. A test of human understanding. Absolutely wonderful.

PROS -
- The sound design in this game is phenomenal! So many VR games lack quality sound design, but not this one. This one sounds like you are standing in a futuristic cavern. Every completion is met with a satisfying BWAH! 
- Graphics are top quality. The design asthetic is meant to be futuristic, and I agree with all the choices made in terms of style and look.
- You can tell that the development team put love into this title, This game is POLISHED.
- Gameplay is surprisingly intuitive, and not glitchy at all. I experienced no dropped frames, no jutter, nothing. Despite the awesomeness of what was happening around me, it still ran wonderfully. And I'm only rocking an AMD Fx8350 and a GTX 1070.
- Have your family try it to add replay value. I can't imagine anyone over the age of fourty not being completely blown away.

CONS -
- Duration. However, I would rather enjoy a rock solid hour of awesome, instead of sit through six hours of crap.
- Price. Although I do think the price is justified due to the amount of time the developers have obviously put into their product, I think full price would have been a little too much (I got it on sale). Still worth it though. 
- The puzzle were pretty easy. Yes, I figured out all the puzzles in an hour, but the way the puzzles work and fit together is fantastic. It all feels interconnected.

I would certainly recommend this game if you want a smooth, beautiful, sci-fi experience. Good stuff.
9/10

32139401.review:
FORM does a thing I've only seen partially achieved by artist Isaac Cohen in his VR experiments (LUNE and Blarp! and My 'lil Donut) and that's create objects that cannot possibly exist in our reality and gives them a form.

Beautifully crafted puzzles that are fairly simple to get through if you apply some logic, but leave you filled with wonderment at the shapes materialising before you.

It's very easy to become disassociated with space when you're standing on an infinitely high column above an infinitely high abyss while an even more infinitely large pyramid burns with fire in front of you. The sense of presence is wonderful as the sound design is for the most part good too, despite some... stilted voice acting - but don't get me wrong - the fact that they went to the trouble to record lines for a game in such a small market as VR shows they're willing to put the effort in to make a game as good as it can be and not just half-ass measures.

Though could possibly do with a hard mode next devs... ;)

Innovative and beautiful, with plenty of varied scene changes and different interactions to figure out the puzzles with. A very good buy for the price.

32121578.review:
Wow! Such a beautiful puzzle game that nails roomscale VR. You operate massive hyper-detailed machinery that transforms right in front of you. The puzzles are somewhat abstract, but do a great job teaching you wordlessly as they react. For example if there's an object that needs to go in a socket, the socket will be reaching out to the object as you move it closers. The audio is also excellent, with each tiny detail scrubbing through satisfying clicks and clacks as you twist things in to place.

There's a tiny story that holds it together. It's well voice and has a nice mix of humor and drama, but it's sets the stage for all the abstract stuff at least existing relative to Earth. Mostly it's like Out of this World or Contact or The Room where you're the scientist transported to another dimension.

My biggest complaint is that some areas of the game frequently drop frames. If the framerate issues can be addressed this might be my favorite VR puzzle game, but till then I'll put it easily in my top 5.

32120615.review:
WOW!!!!!!

Yes, it is short.  Took me just under an hour, but I am also an obsessive puzzle game fanatic.  Others may take a little longer, but I can't imagine it would take more than 1.5  to 2 hrs.

Having said that: WOW!!!!

It just kept stunning me with twisted lanscapes and machinery, like the sacred geometry of an alien mind.  Puzzles felt mysteriously intuitive, despite having to do some really weird stuff to solve some of them.  There was only really one puzzle that I didn't care for, but it wasn't awful or anything, just not as outlandish and creative as the others.

Sound design and score is powerful, chilling stuff, really selling the whole sacred alien revelation thing.  It really felt like the trippiest moments of Contact or Close Encounters.

Lastly, great use of VR!  Lots of intuitive grabbing, pullling, switching, aiming, peeking... none of this would have worked in a traditional game.  It avoids locomotion problems by having puzzles evolve around you, keeping everything in roomscale reach.  Some scripted teleportation occurs, but it all makes sense within the narrative.

I think this might be my favourite VR title so far this year.  Honestly, my only regret is that there isn't more of it.  I actually wish it ended on a cliffhanger, promising more chapters coming soon!  I would buy them in a heartbeat.  For now, I will be playing this through again just for the WOW factor, and will definitely be demoing to friends and family.

Big thanks to the devs, truly awesome work!

40362579.review:
I'm really torn on this. On one hand, FORM is unique. The visuals and sound design are top notch for VR. Some really striking imagery and settings on display. The score fits it perfectly. Animation is interesting and melds the two well... In terms of presentation it's easily top tier out of all the VR experiences I've tried.

On the other hand it's 50 minutes long and none of the puzzles are challenging in the least. There's no replayability either, since it's a completely linear experience. As such I definatly do not think it's worth £10.99. I know distilling a recommendation down to a gameplay/cash ratio isn't usually a good idea, but 50 minutes for 10.99 just doesn't stack up well against other VR things I've tried. 

That being said I'm going to thumb it up anyway. With the caveat of only as long as it's on sale. It's well worth experiencing at least once, and I'll keep it in my library to show friends and family. It's a game that lives and dies entirely on the aesthetics, so make sure you want to spend the better part of an hour in the screenshots above and you'll be in for a treat.

40308632.review:
Form ist ein surreales Puzzlespiel in einer wunderschönen Welt.
(Getestet mit der HTC Vive)
Unsere Aufgabe ist es, als Dr. Eli einen Obelisken zu untersuchen. Während der Untersuchung werden wir in den Obelisken gesogen und befinden uns in einer Art Traumwelt. Dieser gilt es nun zu entkommen, indem wir verschiedene Rätsel lösen.
Und das ist wirklich toll umgesetzt. 
Die Rätsel selbst sind relativ einfach, aber das macht auch nicht den Reiz des Spieles aus. Es ist die Welt um uns herum, die so faszinierend und einfach nur optisch gut umgesetzt ist. 
Das Bedienen der verschiedenen Elemente des Spiels läuft sehr gut, Fortbewegung ist nicht vorgesehen.
Um einen entfernteren Gegenstand zu bekommen, benutzen wir telekinetische Fähigkeiten, mit denen wir die Objekte zu uns ziehen. Hebel und andere Gerätschaften bedienen wir mit der Hand.
Das Spiel ist komplett in englischer Sprache, aber zum Lösen der Rätsel ist das kein größeres Problem. Lediglich die Story verpasst man so, ist aber zu vernachlässigen.
Ich selbst habe das Spiel in einem Rutsch durchgespielt, und war von der Welt von Form begeistert. Leider ist das Spiel mit ca 80 Minuten nicht sonderlich lang, ich hätte auch ohne Probleme weitere Stunden dort verbringen können.
Einen großen Wiederspielwert sehe ich nicht. Es gibt zwar noch einen "Bonusraum" in dem wir Musizieren können, aber das war es dann auch.
Trotzdem gebe ich eine Kaufempfehlung ab, weil das Spiel einfach unglaublich gut aussieht und intuitiv zu Handhaben ist. 
Mir hat es sehr viel Spaß gemacht, die Effekte waren toll und die Rätsel, wenn auch nicht schwer, sehr interessant.

Gruß Ziffi
Ziffi´s Spieletipps als Kurator: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/5837414/

39877018.review:
What a beautiful journey this game was.

Sadly, it is pretty short (I completed the puzzles in one hour) and I hope to see a somehow bigger, more complete version of this game in the future. However, it does not only have one of the best game designs I have ever seen, but also it showcases awesome puzzles that will make your mind blow in many ways.

First of all, FORM is an art masterpiece. Everything you see once you finish the starting zone is astonishingly beautiful. I love abstract concepts, from Quantum Mechanics to impossible shapes, and this game made me speechless with its sheer design and beautifulness. Everything is represented by geometrical constructs that will bend in front of you in ways you had never imagined, breaking your classical concept of reality.

Sound is also pretty amazing. I found myself having eargasms in many moments of this game (especially on the chord tuning puzzle, completing each iteration gave me pure goosebumps in a positive way). Also, this game SHOULD be played with earphones/Deluxe Audio Strap to maximize its immersion factor. The atmosphere and the sound effects will transport you inside this abstract reality like no other game.

Gameplay wise, and as I said before, it is one of the best VR puzzle games out there. Its puzzles reminded me of those found on FRACT OSC: Very abstract components that will not make much sense by themselves, but combined with other ones their purpose gets revealed. Their apparent simplicity will fade out as you unfold polygons and rearrange complex metal structures in order to solve small riddles that will sum parts of a much bigger puzzle. This, combined with a simple yet deep argument makes FORM one of those VR experiences that should be played.

FORM left me wanting more. I really hope Charm Games create a bigger, more advanced version of this surreal, yet beautiful and challenging universe. I totally recommend this game! However, it might be expensive for its current amount of content (15€ for a 1h experience is a bit overpricey, even it being as awesome as FORM is), so I also recommend getting it on a sale!

39869483.review:
Le f. is this? 
This is an abstract puzzler of sorts. Supposed to represent a contact with an alien artifact, and a journey of mind, I suppose. 

Well, does it? 
It tries, but it does a very crappy job of it. 

Why? 
The puzzles are only engaging because they're very easy and you literally can't get stuck at them. The writing is too cliched and isn't fun or interesting at all. Also, I believe, the story doesn't arrive to any kind of resolution whatsoever. 
[spoiler]At the end of my game a humanoid figure appeared and said that I, the smart scientist, can't really comprehend the mystery of the mysterious alien obelisk, despite me sucessfully solving those primary school puzzles for an hour. Then the end credits rolled. Yay for the triumph of scientific method over mysteries of life, huh.[/spoiler]

Is it all bad? 
Welp, pretty much. Everybody praises the visuals, but they didn't impress me at all. The locations weren't interesting, the mechanism design was too eagerly trying to seem alien instead of genuinely feeling like something alien, and it didn't use VR's immersion to achieve anything interesting whatsoever. I wouldn't say it's BAD bad, though, but it's really, really bland and boring. 

Gimme an example!
Ok. Throughout the game you can pick up globes with letters that are supposed to visualize your, a genious scientist's, thoughts. They're not much more scientific than 'Where am I? What is this?'.

How about you shut up and stop this blasphemy?
Ok. Bottom line - go play I Expect You to Die for cool easy VR puzzles. Go play The Room for cute easy non-VR puzzles. Don't waste money on this. If you get it for free and get stuck in a world with no other entertainment whatsoever, well. Maybe give it a shot then, but keep in mind that it's not worth it.

39858975.review:
[b]45 minutes of gameplay to complete[/b], so you'll have to let the game idle to get the trading cards.

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Good visuals and audio
[*]Keeps a solid mystery going
[*]Nice use of "instruments" to reveal parts of the puzzle or give clues
[/list]
[h1]CONS:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Only 45 minutes of gameplay
[*]In some puzzles it may be overly easy to hit the wrong button and have to restart the puzzle
[*]A player probably needs to be at least 10-12 years old based on average height to be able to play (see/manipulate the puzzle parts)
[*]Some of the end puzzles (while I thought would get harder or at least more interesting) turned out to be essentially a game of Simon
[*]Achievements popup at times that might catch your attention to the point where you miss something interesting in game
[*]The shape puzzle with keylike pieces has issues matching/inserting after solving the main puzzle
[*]Some overly similar game puzzles in 45 minutes still felt repetitive
[/list]

Overall, I'd say if you're [i]not[/i] a "puzzle buff" (expecting puzzles you have to really think about) or don't normally play puzzlers, this is a solid [b]3.6 out of 5[/b]. It you're a standard puzzle game player, you probably want to pass on this elementary/intro level puzzler.
